Literature Review: Nonconjugated redox-active polymers (NC-RAPs) have garnered significant attention in recent years due to their potential as metal-free electrode materials for electrochemical energy storage and conversion. The unique properties of NC-RAPs, including cost-effectiveness, good processability, and precise tuning for different battery chemistries, make them an attractive alternative to traditional battery materials. In this review, we will discuss the mechanisms of redox kinetics, molecular design, synthesis, and application of NC-RAPs, as well as their comparison with other redox chemistries. Redox kinetics in NC-RAPs is a critical aspect of their performance. Studies have shown that the redox potential and the rate of electron transfer are influenced by the molecular structure of the polymer. For example, polyquinones have been found to exhibit high redox potential and fast electron transfer rates, making them suitable for high-performance batteries. In contrast, polyketones have been shown to have lower redox potential and slower electron transfer rates, but they can still be used in applications where high stability is required. The molecular design of NC-RAPs is also crucial for their performance. Researchers have used various methods to design and synthesize NC-RAPs, including template polymerization, living radical polymerization, and post-functionalization. These methods allow for the creation of polymers with specific molecular structures and properties, which can be tailored for specific applications. Synthesis of NC-RAPs is another important aspect of their development. Studies have shown that the synthesis method can significantly impact the properties of the polymer. For example, polyimides synthesized using a template polymerization method have been found to have higher conductivity and stability than those synthesized using a living radical polymerization method. NC-RAPs have been applied in various electrochemical energy storage and conversion applications, including batteries, supercapacitors, and fuel cells. Studies have shown that NC-RAPs can exhibit high performance in these applications, including high power density, long cycle life, and good stability. For example, a polyquinone-based polymer has been found to exhibit high power density and long cycle life in a lithium-ion battery. In addition to their performance, NC-RAPs also offer several advantages over traditional battery materials. They are cost-effective, easy to process, and can be designed to have specific properties for different applications. For example, polyketones can be designed to have high stability and low conductivity, making them suitable for applications where high stability is required. Despite the advantages of NC-RAPs, there are still several challenges to their widespread adoption. One of the main challenges is the lack of standardization in the synthesis and characterization of NC-RAPs. This can make it difficult to compare the performance of different NC-RAPs and to develop new materials with improved properties. To address this challenge, researchers have proposed several strategies for standardizing the synthesis and characterization of NC-RAPs. For example, the use of standardized synthesis protocols and characterization methods can help to ensure that NC-RAPs are synthesized and characterized consistently. Additionally, the development of new characterization methods, such as spectroscopic and electrochemical techniques, can provide more detailed information about the properties of NC-RAPs. In conclusion, NC-RAPs offer several advantages over traditional battery materials, including cost-effectiveness, good processability, and precise tuning for different battery chemistries. However, there are still several challenges to their widespread adoption, including the lack of standardization in the synthesis and characterization of NC-RAPs. To address this challenge, researchers must continue to develop new synthesis protocols, characterization methods, and applications for NC-RAPs.
